timeline.title: Started work at SoftBridge
timeline.description: My previous company didn't have much business, so they had to close their doors. I had to find another place to go, and I ended up at this product company developing cool software with cool people.

timeline.title: Finished the SoftUni JS path
timeline.description: I managed to finish SoftUni with an excellent grade even while working, and I got a certificate for my efforts.

timeline.title: Started work at Balkan Software Studio
timeline.description: This was a small local company that allowed me to work on international projects by outsourcing me to bigger teams that would usually be outside of my reach. Here I got to learn the most about what it's like being in a team on a serious project.

timeline.title: Started SoftUni
timeline.description: I wanted to master JavaScript, so I looked for a place to help me specialize in it, and I started the JS path at SoftUni.

timeline.title: Completed a PHP course
timeline.description: The local dev community had a course for PHP, MySQL, and JS that I attended and completed. It was great because it showed me another language besides JS, and I was also among other developers.

timeline.title: Discord Bots
timeline.description: At 16, I started creating scripts for Discord using their API. I had a couple of friends from all around the world helping me learn JavaScript. This would later become "KaoBot", my very first project that serves people.

timeline.title: First JS projects
timeline.description: Up to now, I had created a few HTML and CSS websites, but it wasn't enough. So I found out about and learned a bit of JavaScript, using it to make some elements spin or change color, or for elements to appear when a button was clicked.

timeline.title: First coding experience
timeline.description: I wrote my first ever piece of code at 14. It was a small Ruby text-based adventure game. The best part is that I found a video of it.

projects.name: Portfolio Website
projects.description: The website you are on right now! I decided it is time to collect all of my knowledge and experiences and display them in a single place. A central hub for anyone interested in my work.

projects.name: Amber Camp
projects.description: Real-time chatting application. Separated into two main parts: chatting directly or in groups; answering anonymous questions. This app aims to be a fun text adventure with other people.

projects.name: Stylish Closet
projects.description: Simple shopping site made to practice Vue.js and Tailwind. I made it because I felt like it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

projects.name: React Stores Examples
projects.description: I needed to decide which store was the best for another project, so I decided to test them all out. In the end, I decided to go with "Nano".

projects.name: Hangman Multiplayer
projects.description: Another practice app. I wanted to check out Vue.js, but I decided that I will also check out Tailwind and Socket.io, so I ended up making a game.

projects.name: Books downloader
projects.description: This downloads books from the Pleven medical school library (if you have access to it) and assembles them into whole PDF files. For some reason, on their website, each book is separated into PDFs with 1 page each, and each PDF is on a different route. Looking through the online library is not a fun experience... This app solves this problem.

projects.name: Pantone Wall
projects.description: This application was made to solve a simple problem, fast pantone wallpaper generation. I came up with the idea while browsing an image board, and when I shared the idea there, I was met with support, so I made this.

projects.name: GamBooru
projects.description: GamBooru was inspired by the "booru" image board concept. This is my SoftUni Angular project for the final exam. I wanted to make something meaningful and fun but also different from all other projects.

projects.name: Cool Feed
projects.description: My first React website. I had to make it for the SoftUni exam, so I stuck with something simple and improved on it. This social media clone expands on the traditional concept by adding unlimited likes.

projects.name: Rock Paper Scissors
projects.description: After my success with KaoBot's mini-games, I was inspired to make a full game! I decided to make Uno online, but that was a tall task, so I practiced multiplayer, user accounts, scores, game state, and other things I would need with this game.

projects.name: KaoBot
projects.description: This is more or less how I got into JavaScript. At first, this bot started as a simple logging script to help me moderate my community, but with time I expanded and added features to it. It soon grew to serve over 400 communities.

js.details: Out of all frameworks (or libraries), I have the most professional experience with React, having used it to build production-ready code such as banking software and administrative panels.
Vue is my personal go-to framework, having used it for a decent amount of admin dashboards and settings panels at work, making it my second most used in a professional setting.
I have also used Svelte in a professional setting for a questionnaire app. This website also uses it because its built-in functionalities are everything I need for this kind of quick project.
Running JavaScript on the server is how I started with this language. Node has allowed me to learn and expand my skills like no other tool.
Express was my very first experience with web programming, using EJS to create SSR websites. I've used it to build a literature guide website and my RPS game.
Although I have used this tool for a long time, only recently was I able to unlock its full potential. I really enjoy real-time updates, and this is my tool of choice.

other.details: For most of my personal projects, I have used Mongo. I like the simplicity of document-based databases, so this, plus the Mongoose package, are my tools of choice.
All of the professional applications I have worked with used some flavor of SQL, be it Postgres, MySQL, or something else.
I use Linux as my main operating system, so I am familiar and comfortable with using the terminal.
Git is a part of almost all of my projects, be it for work or not; everything is version controlled with it. Usually through GitHub, but I have also used GitLab and BitBucket.
Along with Jira, I am familiar with SCRUM and all the artifacts and ceremonies that come with it. I've used these tools/methods throughout most of my professional work.
Most of the tests I have written are unit tests with Jest. I also have experience with Mocha & Chai, Bun tests, and Puppeteer.

softSkills.details: It is easy to work in a team if we all get along, so I always strive to get to know everyone and also do my part.
I find it very easy to adapt to my current situation, even if I start from zero. This is true for everything I do, getting to know my colleagues, code, and the company.
Communication is the most important part of any process in life. That is why I value it so highly.
For most solutions, we often need creativity. It's a valuable skill to be able to come up with alternative ways of solving problems.
